results.title: A Filmmaker’s Journey to the Center of Celine Dion
results.abstract: In her kooky, rambunctious biopic “Aline,” the French comedian Valérie Lemercier drew from her own life to play the Quebecois pop star at every stage of hers.

multimedia.caption: Valérie Lemercier even plays a 5-year-old version of Celine Dion in her film “Aline.” “Little girls, more than little boys, fascinate me — what they say, what they imagine, what goes on in their mind.”
multimedia.copyright: Cedrine Scheidig for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Valérie Lemercier even plays a 5-year-old version of Celine Dion in her film “Aline.” “Little girls, more than little boys, fascinate me — what they say, what they imagine, what goes on in their mind.”
multimedia.copyright: Cedrine Scheidig for The New York Times

results.title: Representation or Stereotype? Deaf Viewers Are Torn Over ‘CODA’
results.abstract: They’re hesitant to criticize the Oscar-winning film because it showcases deaf actors and lives, but some find its hearing perspective frustrating or even upsetting.

multimedia.caption: Emilia Jones (with Eugenio Derbez at the piano) plays a hearing teenager whose desire to sing confounds her family. Critics say they are confounded by the film’s depiction of the relationship between deafness and music.

Emilia Jones (with Eugenio Derbez at the piano) plays a hearing teenager whose desire to sing confounds her family. Critics say they are confounded by the film’s depiction of the relationship between deafness and music.

results.title: When the Master of the Erotic Thriller Fails to Thrill
results.abstract: Adrian Lyne used to make deranged romps animated by conservative masculine anxieties. By the time of “Deep Water,” his muse — the all-powerful white man — had lost his grip.

multimedia.caption: “Deep Water,” starring Ana de Armas and Ben Affleck and directed by the master of the erotic thriller, Adrian Lyne, proves neither erotic nor thrilling.
multimedia.copyright: Claire Folger/20th Century Studios and Hulu

results.title: The Slap Wasn’t the Only Astonishing Thing About the Oscars
results.abstract: One stretch of the broadcast featured a remarkable convergence of Black celebrities, our critic writes. But in the midst of it all, Will Smith’s victory became a defeat.

multimedia.caption: Will Smith during his acceptance speech for the best actor Oscar for his role as Richard Williams in “King Richard.” Earlier he had slapped Chris Rock for a comment about his wife, Jada Pinkett Smith.

results.title: Does the Academy Hold Movies in Contempt? Our Critics Wonder.
